title: Phil Jackson took a weird, veiled Twitter shot at Carmelo Anthony
text:
Phil Jackson took a weird, veiled Twitter shot at Carmelo Anthony We break down Phil Jackson's tweet, phrase by phrase. Post to Facebook Phil Jackson took a weird, veiled Twitter shot at Carmelo Anthony We break down Phil Jackson's tweet, phrase by phrase.  //ftw.usatoday.com/2017/02/phil-jackson-carmelo-anthony-tweet-trade-rumors-cavaliers/   Phil Jackson took a weird, veiled Twitter shot at Carmelo Anthony Adi Joseph , USA TODAY Sports 4:43   95 Shares 
Phil Jackson tweets are basically like James Joyce's writing. You need to unpack every word slowly, consider the connotations and use loose definitions of words to get the point. 
Take today's offering from the Knicks president - his first tweet since Dec. 27: Bleacher's Ding almost rings the bell, but I learned you don't change the spot on a leopard with Michael Graham in my CBA daze. â€” Phil Jackson (@PhilJackson11) February 7, 2017 
OK, let's translate this, phrase by phrase: 
Bleacher's Ding 
That's clearly a reference to Bleacher Report 's Kevin Ding, who had a column today criticizing Carmelo Anthony for not fulfilling the role of a Phil Jackson Superstar (in other words, Michael Jordan and Kobe Bryant). 
almost rings the bell, 
In other words, Jackson says Ding's column was pretty close to the truth. That in itself is a pretty harsh thing to say about your team's highest paid and highest-profile player. Ding's column , in no uncertain terms, says Anthony doesn't care about winning enough. But Jackson left himself some room with that "almost," right? 
but I learned you don't change the spot on a leopard 
Oh, nope. Phil's grievance isn't with the stuff about Anthony but rather the stuff about him. Here's the key sentence in question: "Jackson undoubtedly overestimated his own ability-perhaps you've heard something lately about the no-trade clause he gifted to Melo in 2014-to kindle Anthony's evolution from superstar to winning superstar." 
with Michael Graham in my CBA 
Graham was Patrick Ewing's co-star on those great 1980s Georgetown teams. He was a very talented power forward who didn't have enough discipline to make the NBA, but he did play for Jackson on the Albany Patroons. And he got dismissed midseason after fighting with Jackson during the game, as this Washingtonian profile of Graham now details . 
daze. 
This is hippy for "days." 
So what does Phil Jackson mean with all of this? He's trying to tell us that he knew he couldn't change Anthony, whom he gave a five-year near-maximum contract with a player option and a no-trade clause. That deal came after Anthony had played for Jackson for a year. 
Jackson also set Anthony up with teammates that didn't fit his playing style, and his persistent negativity surely hasn't helped matters. 
But these days, the goal seems to be getting Anthony to waive his no-trade clause - and ideally to get Kevin Love back in return . So maybe a public shot on Twitter is the right move. At the very least, it's something that happened. Read or Share this story: http://ftw.usatoday.com/2017/02/phil-jackson-carmelo-anthony-tweet-trade-rumors-cavaliers/ Most Popular
